Header:
Understanding cancer requires an accurate picture of cells and how they organize within the tissue. [ChipCytometry](https://canopybiosciences.com/chipcytometry/) propels scientific understanding by offering a complete solution for spatially resolved multiplexing to visualize and quantify cells within their native environment. 

In this exemplar dataset, a breast cancer tissue section was stained with the ChipCytometry 21-plex Immuno-oncology (IO) Spatial Phenotyping Panel. Click the arrows to explore the power of ChipCytometry for highly multiplexed spatial profiling of human cancer.

Waypoints.Name: Tissue Overview
Waypoints.Description: In this breast cancer specimen, the invasive tumor (Pan-cytokeratin+/HER-2+) is characterized by poorly differentiated epithelial cells. Tumor tissue surrounds a small region of normal tissue, characterized by well-organized epithelial cells (Pan-cytokeratin+).

Waypoints.Name: Tumor Tissue
Waypoints.Description: Invasive breast carcinoma is characterized by cancer cells that have infiltrated the tissue and moved beyond the normal lobules and ducts. In this specimen, epithelial tumor cells (Pan-cytokeratin+/HER-2+) are noted by their high levels of HER-2 expression and poor differentiation.

Waypoints.Name: Normal Tissue
Waypoints.Description: Normal breast epithelium forms well-organized structures like ducts and lobules. In this region of normal tissue, the epithelial cells (Pan-cytokeratin+) do not express high levels of HER-2.

Waypoints.Name: Immune Populations
Waypoints.Description: The 21-plex IO Spatial Phenotyping Panel is designed for broad spatial profiling of a variety of immune populations (CD45+). This sample contains a variety of T cell subpopulations. Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+), helper T cells (CD4+), and regulatory T cells (CD4+/FoxP3+) quantified with the ChipCytometry Data Analysis Center.

Waypoints.Name: PD-1 Expressing Immune Cells
Waypoints.Description: PD-1 helps to regulate the immune system’s response by suppressing T cell inflammatory activity and is thus target of many immunotherapies. In this breast cancer specimen, PD-1 is found on the surface of a subset of T cells.
